title: Does human consciousness need a human body? Can they be separated? - Quora

response.answer_text: The consciousness that you are experiencing this moment with isn't yours. The universe itself is conscious in you. This is an important distinction, because we all tend to get wrapped up in illusions of identity and miss this universal connection. It's like they say in zen: beginner's mind is Buddha mind. And it's all one mind, plugging into the experiential flow of a human organism. And a human organism is a damn cool thing to experience life - your cosmic self - with. Everybody has their own take on this, because the forms this universal consciousness takes are infinite and truth itself can't be spoken. So here's my two cents in the infinite tip jar. I think one way of understanding interconnectedness is to realize that words like the concept itself doesn't do it justice. It's just a word, a symbol. If you hold on to it too much you may get rightfully confused as to how your perspective of reality, right now through your senses, could possibly be a perspective of and by "everything", "The one"... since it's so trivial, so singular, so localised... how can "you" possibly be everything? Well, you have to drop words and appearances if you want to really feel it. What you think you are is an idea. It's a thought the brain, and by extension the universe, is having. Why "by extension the universe"? Because your brain is the way it is because of your parents' genes, actions and the events in the extended environment. Every moment in time that passes adds an incomprehensible amount new causes and effects to the flow of matter and energy that simply aren't and can't be understood. The universe is a flow. You can play a game of "follow the chain of events" which is what science is, and you may learn more about the chain, but you won't get to an end. Even if you do, there is always the potential metaphysical extension to the chain you can't comprehend. This is something you could meditate on. Your I is a thought and it can only be what it is if the rest of the universe is what it is. It is an incarnation of sentience, spawned as a particular arrangement of energy, which all comes from and is founded on the same source which we call the universe. What I like about the "no self" philosophy of Buddhism is that it helps you to let go of the dualistic view where you are a "soul" experiencing a "greater soul" (the universe). You are not a soul, there is no such thing, unless you look at it from the most trivial perspective imaginable, the one I'm guessing most of us are experiencing day to day and probably right now. You are YOU only as long as your brain conjures up, and is self-aware of, an identity. When that identity is either dropped or seen through you get the enlightenment all the philosophers are talking about. You aren't "in" the universe... you are so intertwined with what we call the universe that you can be nothing but the universe itself.

Does human consciousness need a human body? Can they be separated? Yes. Consciousness is the running, pre-installed firmware and software, and the brain is the ROM, RAM, motherboard and processor, and there's no backup drive. Consciousness needs the brain and then, the parts of the brain whose functions contribute to consciousness. Remove or damage or kill off those, and consciousness ceases. Consciousness can't even move to a neighbouring, undamaged part of the brain. Billions of deceased humans and no continuing consciousness thereof tends to suggest that this has always been the case.

We are seeing a dead body getting separated from consciousness. ( this answers 2nd part of question) No special evidence is needed. Consciousness is ONE without a second. There's no special human consciousness and animal consciousness etc. The instruments that utilise this Spiritual Energy— the consciousness may differ like a human brain for humans , dog brain for a dog etc. For unicellular organism the cell itself serves as a sort of brain , hence its urge to live that causes to change its structure to resist adverse effects of drugs that tend to kill it. To put it straight — it is human body that need consciousness to be alive and exist ; not the vice versa. Consciousness is in no need of human or any other body ; in fact anything else whatsoever.

I recommend listening to Dr. Bruce Greyson’s youtube talk “Is Consciousness Created by the Brain?” In it, Dr. Greyson (UVA, DOPS) cites the medical cases that show that the brain is not the only source of consciousness, and further there are numerous medical cases where the brain is not functioning and yet consciousness occurs.  Further, you’ll find peer reviewed science articles in “Irriducible Mind” by Ed Kelly PhD that cite different examples, but the same conclusion - the brain is not the only source of consciousness, but it may very well function as a receiver of consciousness.

Not without alternative hardware. Pretty sure that consciousness requires some significant computational activity which we usually call awareness. Currently the computational hardware needed is a healthy, non-sleeping human brain. Computation is substrate independent. So in theory it could run on anything. So new hardware might become available. But consciousness cannot wander free from all hardware, a disembodied soul-cloud, floating free from the constraints of mortal flesh, cannot happen. It can merely imagine that.

Human consciousness is of two types - gross and subtle. Gross consciousness needs a human body. Subtle consciousness is the detachable part of gross consciousness. One experiences yoga through subtle consciousness that travels out of the body linked with the soul when the soul gets separated from the body through meditation.

We need a body to do sadhana, which is spiritual practice, especially in the form of meditation. This is why so many beings seek a human body. This is a highly prized commodity and should never be undervalued. Conscious can be separated. Dissociation is one example. Death is another.
